etymologies: Middle English: from Old French menestral ‘entertainer, servant’, via Provençal from late Latin ministerialis ‘servant’ (see ministerial)

definitions: a medieval singer or musician, especially one who sang or recited lyric or heroic poetry to a musical accompaniment for the nobility

examples.text: they listened to the minstrels singing songs of knightly prowess

definitions: a member of a band of entertainers, typically white actors with blackened faces, who performed in a type of stage entertainment prevalent in the US in the 19th and early 20th centuries, featuring songs, dances, and formulaic comic routines based on stereotyped depictions of black Americans

examples.text: the exaggerated dialect of blackface minstrels

shortDefinitions: member of band of entertainers with blackened faces
